select.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

select.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

select.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

select.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

select.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

select.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

select.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

select.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

select.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

select.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

select.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

select.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

select.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

select.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

select.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

select.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

select.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

select.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

select.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

select.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

select.label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

select.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

select.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

select.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

select.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

select.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

    }
}

backgroundColor: {

select.label.rich.<style_name>.borderTyp.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOff.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

select.edgeLabel.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.verti.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.lineH.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.backg.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.borde.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.paddi.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.shado.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.heigh.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.textB.desc:

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

select.edgeLabel.rich.<style_name>.textS.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

selectedMode.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Selected mode. It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be false to disable it.

Besides, it can be set to 'single', 'multiple' or 'series', for single selection, multiple selections and whole series selection.

'series' is supported since v5.3.0

categories.desc: The categories of node, which is optional. If there is a classification of nodes, the category of each node can be assigned through data[i].category. And the style of category will also be applied to the style of nodes. categories can also be used in legend.

categories.name.desc: Name of category, which is used to correspond with legend and the content of tooltip.

categories.symbol.desc:
Symbol of node of this category.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

categories.symbolSize.desc: node of this category symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

categories.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of node of this category symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

categories.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

categories.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of node of this category symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

categories.itemStyle.desc: The style of node in this category.

categories.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

categories.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

categories.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

categories.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

categories.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

categories.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

categories.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

categories.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

categories.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

categories.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

categories.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

categories.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

categories.label.desc: The label style of node in this category.

categories.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

categories.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

categories.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

categories.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

categories.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {@score}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

categories.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{

    rich: {
        a: {

categories.emphasis.desc: Emphasis state of nodes in this category.

categories.emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since v5.2.0, it can be set to 'inherit' in the emphasis state to disable color highlight.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderColo.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidt.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderDash.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMite.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColo.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffs.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

categories.emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

categories.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

categories.emphasis.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

categories.emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

categories.emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

categories.emphasis.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

categories.emphasis.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

categories.emphasis.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

categories.emphasis.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

categories.emphasis.label.backgroundColo.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

categories.emphasis.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

categories.emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

categories.emphasis.label.borderDashOffs.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.emphasis.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

categories.emphasis.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

categories.emphasis.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

categories.emphasis.label.textBorderColo.desc:
Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

categories.emphasis.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

categories.emphasis.label.textBorderDash.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.emphasis.label.textShadowOffs.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

categories.emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

categories.emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

categories.emphasis.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

Shadow Y offset of the text block.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.select.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Select state of nodes in this category.

categories.select.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

If data can be selected. Available when selectedMode is used. Can be used to disable selection for part of the data.

categories.select.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

categories.select.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

categories.select.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

categories.select.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

categories.select.itemStyle.borderDashOf.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.select.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

categories.select.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

categories.select.itemStyle.borderMiterL.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

categories.select.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

categories.select.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

categories.select.itemStyle.shadowOffset.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

categories.select.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

categories.select.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

categories.select.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

categories.select.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

categories.select.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

categories.select.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

categories.select.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

categories.select.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

categories.select.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

categories.select.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

categories.select.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

the text fragment border type.

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

categories.select.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

categories.select.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

categories.select.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

categories.select.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

categories.select.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

autoCurveness.desc:
For the situation where there are multiple links between nodes, the curveness of each link is automatically calculated, not enabled by default.

When set true to enable automatic curvature calculation, the default edge curvenness array length is 20, if the number of edges between two nodes is more than 20, please use number or Array to set the edge curvenness array.

When set to number, it indicates the length of the edge curvenness array between two nodes, and the calculation result is given by the internal algorithm.

When set to Array, it means that the curveness array is directly specified, and the multilateral curveness is directly selected from the array.

Notice： if lineStyle.curveness has been set, this property is invalid.

data.desc:
Nodes list of graph.

data: [{
    name: '1',
    x: 10,
    y: 10,
    value: 10
}, {
    name: '2',
    x: 100,
    y: 100,
    value: 20,
    symbolSize: 20,
    itemStyle: {
        color: 'red'
    }
}]

data.fixed.desc: If node are fixed when doing force directed layout.

data.category.desc: Index of category which the data item belongs to.

data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of node of this category.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

data.symbolSize.desc: node of this category symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of node of this category symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

data.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of node of this category symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

color. Color is taken from option.color Palette by default.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

data.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

data.emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since v5.2.0, it can be set to 'inherit' in the emphasis state to disable color highlight.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

data.select.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

data.select.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

data.select.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border type.

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

data.select.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

data.select.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

data.select.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.select.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.
