markLine.data.1.type.desc:
Special label types, are used to label maximum value, minimum value and so on.

Options are:

  • 'min' minimum value.
  • 'max' maximum value.
  • 'average' average value.
  • 'median' median value.

markLine.data.1.valueIndex.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be 0 (for xAxis, or radiusAxis), or 1 (for yAxis, or angleAxis). Dimension of the first numeric axis is used by default.

markLine.data.1.valueDim.desc: Works only when type is assigned. It is used to state the dimension used to calculate maximum value or minimum value. It may be the direct name of a dimension, like x, or angle for line charts, or open, or close for candlestick charts.

markLine.data.1.coord.desc:
Coordinates of the starting point or ending point, whose format depends on the coordinate of the series. It can be x, and y for rectangular coordinates, or radius, and angle for polar coordinates.

Notice: For axis with axis.type 'category':

  • If coord value is number, it represents index of axis.data.
  • If coord value is string, it represents concrete value in axis.data. Please notice that in this case xAxis.data must not be written as [number, number, ...], but can only be written [string, string, ...]. Otherwise it is not able to be located by markPoint / markLine.

For example:

{
    xAxis: {
        type: 'category',
        data: ['5', '6', '9', '13', '19', '33']
        // As mentioned above, data should not be [5, 6, 9, 13, 19, 33] here.
    },
    series: {
        type: 'line',
        data: [11, 22, 33, 44, 55, 66],
        markPoint: { // markLine is in the same way.
            data: [{
                coord: [5, 33.4], // The number 5 represents xAxis.data[5], that is, '33'.
                // coord: ['5', 33.4] // The string '5' represents the '5' in xAxis.data.
            }]
        }
    }
}

markLine.data.1.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.1.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.xAxis.desc:
Markline at x at given value, which only works for single data item. Example:

data: [{
    name: 'A vertical line with X valued 100',
    xAxis: 100
}]

or if xAxis is in 'time' type, it can be set as:

{
    name: 'A vertical line with X valued "2020-01-01"',
    xAxis: '2020-01-01'
}]

markLine.data.1.yAxis.desc:
Markline at y at given value, which only works for single data item. Example:

data: [{
    name: 'A horizontal line with X valued 100',
    yAxis: 100
}]

or if yAxis is in 'time' type, it can be set as:

{
    name: 'A horizontal line with Y valued "2020-01-01"',
    yAxis: '2020-01-01'
}]

markLine.data.1.symbol.desc:
Symbol of ending point.

Icon types provided by ECharts includes

'circle', 'rect', 'roundRect', 'triangle', 'diamond', 'pin', 'arrow', 'none'

It can be set to an image with 'image://url' , in which URL is the link to an image, or dataURI of an image.

An image URL example:

'image://http://example.website/a/b.png'

A dataURI example:

'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'

Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via 'path://' in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to SVG PathData for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'

markLine.data.1.symbolSize.desc: ending point symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like 10, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, [20, 10] means symbol width is 20, and height is10.

markLine.data.1.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of ending point symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when symbol is set to be 'arrow' in markLine, symbolRotate value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.1.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of path://.

markLine.data.1.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of ending point symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, [0, '-50%'] means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with lineStyle of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.cap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.join.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.1.label.desc: Label of this data item, which will be merged with label of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:

  • 'start' starting point of the line.
  • 'middle' middle point of the line.
  • 'end' ending point of the line.

Since v4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'.

'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with label.distance.

markLine.data.1.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.1.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {d}: the percent.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {d}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markLine.data.1.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

markLine.data.1.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markLine.data.1.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markLine.data.1.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markLine.data.1.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markLine.data.1.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markLine.data.1.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

markLine.data.1.label.textBorderDashOffs.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markLine.data.1.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

markLine.data.1.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markLine.data.1.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

markLine.data.1.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

markLine.data.1.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markLine.data.1.label.rich.<style_name>..desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

font style.

Options are:

  • 'normal'
  • 'italic'
  • 'oblique'

font thick weight.

Options are:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

font family.

Can also be 'serif' , 'monospace', ...
font size.

Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Border width of the text fragment.

the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.
Border radius of the text fragment.

Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.
Shadow color of the text block.
Show blur of the text block.
Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Stroke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.
Shadow color of the text itself.
Shadow blue of the text itself.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.cap.desc:

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.miter.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.shado.desc:

markLine.data.1.emphasis.lineStyle.curve.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:

  • 'start' starting point of the line.
  • 'middle' middle point of the line.

Since v4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'.

'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with label.distance.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {d}: the percent.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {d}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.borderCol.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.borderTyp.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With dashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.dashOffse.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With type , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.cap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.join.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the miterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.miterLimi.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when join is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.shadowBlu.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.shadowCol.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.shadowOff.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:

  • 'start' starting point of the line.
  • 'middle' middle point of the line.
  • 'end' ending point of the line.

Since v4.7.0, more label positions are supported: 'start', 'middle', 'end', 'insideStartTop', 'insideStartBottom', 'insideMiddleTop', 'insideMiddleBottom', 'insideEndTop', 'insideEndBottom'.

'insideMiddleBottom' is the same as 'middle'. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with label.distance.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.1.blur.label.formatter.desc:
Data label formatter, which supports string template and callback function. In either form, \n is supported to represent a new line.

String template

Model variation includes:

  • {a}: series name.
  • {b}: the name of a data item.
  • {c}: the value of a data item.
  • {d}: the percent.
  • {@xxx}: the value of a dimension named 'xxx', for example, {@product} refers the value of 'product' dimension.
  • {@[n]}: the value of a dimension at the index of n, for example, {@[3]} refers the value at dimensions[3].

example: 

formatter: '{b}: {d}'

Callback function

Callback function is in form of:

(params: Object|Array) => string

where params is the single dataset needed by formatter, which is formed as:

{
    componentType: 'series',
    // Series type
    seriesType: string,
    // Series index in option.series
    seriesIndex: number,
    // Series name
    seriesName: string,
    // Data name, or category name
    name: string,
    // Data index in input data array
    dataIndex: number,
    // Original data as input
    data: Object,
    // Value of data. In most series it is the same as data.
    // But in some series it is some part of the data (e.g., in map, radar)
    value: number|Array|Object,
    // encoding info of coordinate system
    // Key: coord, like ('x' 'y' 'radius' 'angle')
    // value: Must be an array, not null/undefined. Contain dimension indices, like:
    // {
    //     x: [2] // values on dimension index 2 are mapped to x axis.
    //     y: [0] // values on dimension index 0 are mapped to y axis.
    // }
    encode: Object,
    // dimension names list
    dimensionNames: Array<String>,
    // data dimension index, for example 0 or 1 or 2 ...
    // Only work in `radar` series.
    dimensionIndex: number,
    // Color of data
    color: string
}

How to use encode and dimensionNames?

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    source: [
        ['Matcha Latte', 43.3, 85.8, 93.7],
        ['Milk Tea', 83.1, 73.4, 55.1],
        ['Cheese Cocoa', 86.4, 65.2, 82.5],
        ['Walnut Brownie', 72.4, 53.9, 39.1]
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.encode.y[0]]

When the dataset is like

dataset: {
    dimensions: ['product', '2015', '2016', '2017'],
    source: [
        {product: 'Matcha Latte', '2015': 43.3, '2016': 85.8, '2017': 93.7},
        {product: 'Milk Tea', '2015': 83.1, '2016': 73.4, '2017': 55.1},
        {product: 'Cheese Cocoa', '2015': 86.4, '2016': 65.2, '2017': 82.5},
        {product: 'Walnut Brownie', '2015': 72.4, '2016': 53.9, '2017': 39.1}
    ]
}

We can get the value of the y-axis via

params.value[params.dimensionNames[params.encode.y[0]]]

markLine.animationThreshold.desc: Whether to set graphic number threshold to animation. Animation will be disabled when graphic number is larger than threshold.

markLine.animationDuration.desc:
Duration of the first animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect:

animationDuration: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

markLine.animationEasing.desc: Easing method used for the first animation. Varied easing effects can be found at easing effect example.

markLine.animationDelay.desc:
Delay before updating the first animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect.

For example:

animationDelay: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

See this example for more information.

markLine.animationDurationUpdate.desc:
Time for animation to complete, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effect:

animationDurationUpdate: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

markLine.animationDelayUpdate.desc:
Delay before updating animation, which supports callback function for different data to have different animation effects.

For example:

animationDelayUpdate: function (idx) {
    // delay for later data is larger
    return idx * 100;
}

See this example for more information.

markArea.desc: Used to mark an area in chart. For example, mark a time interval.

markArea.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markArea.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markArea.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

markArea.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markArea.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markArea.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }

    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markArea.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markArea.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markArea.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markArea.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markArea.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markArea.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markArea.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

markArea.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markArea.emphasis.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

markArea.emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markArea.emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markArea.blur.desc:
Since v5.0.0

Configurations of blur state. Whether to blur follows the series.

markArea.blur.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markArea.blur.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

markArea.blur.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markArea.blur.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

markArea.blur.label.color.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.blur.label.align.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

markArea.blur.label.verticalAlign.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

markArea.blur.label.lineHeight.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

markArea.blur.label.backgroundColor.desc:
Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.blur.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markArea.blur.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markArea.blur.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markArea.blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markArea.blur.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.blur.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With textBorderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}

markArea.blur.label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.blur.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

markArea.blur.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markArea.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

markArea.blur.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

markArea.blur.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.co.desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.al.desc:
Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.ve.desc:
Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {

            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.li.desc:
Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {

        }
    }

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.bo.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.pa.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

  • padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]: represents padding of [top, right, bottom, left].
  • padding: 4: represents padding: [4, 4, 4, 4].
  • padding: [3, 4]: represents padding: [3, 4, 3, 4].

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.sh.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.wi.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.he.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.te.desc:
Stroke color of the text.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

Stroke line type of the text.

To set the line dash offset. With textBorderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.
Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markArea.blur.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.data.desc:
The scope of the area is defined by data, which is an array with two item, representing the left-top point and the right-bottom point of rectangle area. Each item can be defined as follows:

  1. Specify the coordinate in screen coordinate system using x, y, where the unit is pixel (e.g., the value is 5), or percent (e.g., the value is '35%').

  1. Specify the coordinate in data coordinate system (i.e., cartesian) using coord, which can be also set as 'min', 'max', 'average' (e.g, coord: [23, 'min'], or coord: ['average', 'max']).

  2. Locate the point on the min value or max value of series.data using type, where valueIndex or valueDim can be used to specify the dimension on which the min, max or average are calculated.

  3. If in cartesian, you can only specify xAxis or yAxis to define a mark area based on only X or Y axis, see sample scatter-weight

The priority follows as above if more than one above definition used.

data: [


    [
        {
            name: 'From average to max',
            type: 'average'
        },
        {
            type: 'max'
        }
    ],

    [
        {
            name: 'Mark area between two points in data coordiantes',
            coord: [10, 20]
        },
        {
            coord: [20, 30]
        }
    ], [
        {
            name: 'From 60 to 80',
            yAxis: 60
        },
        {
            yAxis: 80
        }
    ], [
        {
            name: 'Mark area covers all data'
            coord: ['min', 'min']
        },
        {
            coord: ['max', 'max']
        }
    ],
[
        {
            name: 'Mark area in two screen points',
            x: 100,
            y: 100
        }, {
            x: '90%',
            y: '10%'
        }
    ]
]

markArea.data.0.type.desc:
Specify this item is on min or max or average value.

Options:

  • 'min' max value.
  • 'max' min value.
  • 'average' average value.

markArea.data.0.valueIndex.desc: Specify the dimension on which min, max, average are calculated, available when type used. The value can be 0 (means xAxis, radiusAxis) or 1 (means yAxis, angleAxis), using the dimension of the first axis by default.

markArea.data.0.valueDim.desc: Specify the dimension on which min, max, average are calculated, available when type used. The value can be the name of the dimension (for example, the value can be x, angle in line chart, and open, close in candlestick).

markArea.data.0.coord.desc: The format is [start coordinate, end coordinate], where the coordinate system can be x, y on cartesian, or radius, angle on polar.

markArea.data.0.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markArea.data.0.x.desc: x value on screen coordinate system, can be pixel number (like 5), or percent value (like '20%').

markArea.data.0.y.desc: y value on screen coordinate system, can be pixel number (like 5), or percent value (like '20%').

markArea.data.0.itemStyle.desc: Style of the item. itemStyle of start point and end point will be merged together.

color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markArea.data.0.label.rich.<style_name>..desc:
text color.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

font style.

Options are:

  • 'normal'
  • 'italic'
  • 'oblique'

font thick weight.

Options are:

  • 'normal'
  • 'bold'
  • 'bolder'
  • 'lighter'
  • 100 | 200 | 300 | 400...

font family.

Can also be 'serif' , 'monospace', ...
font size.

Horizontal alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'left'
  • 'center'
  • 'right'

If align is not set in rich, align in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    align: right,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `align` is not set, then it will be right
        }
    }
}

Vertical alignment of text, automatic by default.

Options are:

  • 'top'
  • 'middle'
  • 'bottom'

If verticalAlign is not set in rich, verticalAlign in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    verticalAlign: bottom,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `verticalAlign` is not set, then it will be bottom
        }
    }
}

Line height of the text fragment.

If lineHeight is not set in rich, lineHeight in parent level will be used. For example:

{
    lineHeight: 56,
    rich: {
        a: {
            // `lineHeight` is not set, then it will be 56
        }
    }
}

Background color of the text fragment.

Can be color string, like '#123234', 'red', 'rgba(0,23,11,0.3)'.

Or image can be used, for example:

backgroundColor: {
    image: 'xxx/xxx.png'
    // It can be URL of a image,
    // or dataURI,
    // or HTMLImageElement,
    // or HTMLCanvasElement.
}

width or height can be specified when using background image, or auto adapted by default.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

Border color of the text fragment.

If set as 'inherit', the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.
Border width of the text fragment.

the text fragment border type.

Possible values are:

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see backgroundColor).

Notice, width and height specifies the width and height of the content, without padding.

width can also be percent string, like '100%', which represents the percent of contentWidth (that is, the width without padding) of its container box. It is based on contentWidth because that each text fragment is layout based on the content box, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on outerWith in prectice.

Notice, width and height only work when rich specified.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.disabled.desc:
Since v5.3.0

Whether to disable the emphasis state.

When emphasis state is disabled. There will be no highlight effect when the mouse hovered the element, tooltip is triggered, or the legend is hovered. It can be used to improve interaction fluency when there are massive graphic elements.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markArea.data.0.emphasis.itemStyle.borde.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.itemStyle.shado.desc:

}
Shadow color. Support same format as color.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.itemStyle.opaci.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when width is set.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the text and trailing with ellipsis.
  • 'break' Break by word
  • 'breakAll' Break by character.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc:
Ellipsis to be displayed when overflow is set to truncate.

  • 'truncate' Truncate the overflow lines.

markArea.data.0.emphasis.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markArea.data.0.blur.label.rich.desc:
"Rich text styles" can be defined in this rich property. For example:

label: {
    // Styles defined in 'rich' can be applied to some fragments
    // of text by adding some markers to those fragment, like
    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.
    // `'\n'` is the newline character.
    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

For more details, see Rich Text please.

markArea.data.1.type.desc:
Specify this item is on min or max or average value.

Options:

  • 'min' max value.
  • 'max' min value.
  • 'average' average value.

markArea.data.1.valueIndex.desc: Specify the dimension on which min, max, average are calculated, available when type used. The value can be 0 (means xAxis, radiusAxis) or 1 (means yAxis, angleAxis), using the dimension of the first axis by default.

markArea.data.1.valueDim.desc: Specify the dimension on which min, max, average are calculated, available when type used. The value can be the name of the dimension (for example, the value can be x, angle in line chart, and open, close in candlestick).

markArea.data.1.coord.desc: The format is [start coordinate, end coordinate], where the coordinate system can be x, y on cartesian, or radius, angle on polar.

markArea.data.1.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markArea.data.1.x.desc: x value on screen coordinate system, can be pixel number (like 5), or percent value (like '20%').

markArea.data.1.y.desc: y value on screen coordinate system, can be pixel number (like 5), or percent value (like '20%').

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.desc: Style of the item. itemStyle of start point and end point will be merged together.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderDashOffs.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.borderMiterLim.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.data.1.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.data.1.label.desc: Label style of the item. Label style of start point and end point will be merged together.

markArea.data.1.label.position.desc:
Label position.

Followings are the options:

  • [x, y]

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

      // Absolute pixel values
  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'left'
  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'
  • 'inside'
  • 'insideLeft'
  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'
  • 'insideTopLeft'
  • 'insideBottomLeft'
  • 'insideTopRight'
  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

markArea.data.1.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').

See: label position.

markArea.data.1.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: label rotation.

markArea.data.1.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: [30, 40] means move 30 horizontally and move 40 vertically.

label: {

    // `{styleName|text content text content}`.

    formatter: [
        '{a|Style "a" is applied to this snippet}'
        '{b|Style "b" is applied to this snippet}This snippet use default style{x|use style "x"}'
    ].join('\n'),

    rich: {
        a: {
            color: 'red',
            lineHeight: 10
        },
        b: {
            backgroundColor: {
                image: 'xxx/xxx.jpg'
            },
            height: 40
        },
        x: {
            fontSize: 18,
            fontFamily: 'Microsoft YaHei',
            borderColor: '#449933',
            borderRadius: 4
        },
        ...
    }
}

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.

Supports setting as solid color using rgb(255,255,255), rgba(255,255,255,1), #fff, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see option.color for details

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderCol.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of color.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderWid.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderTyp.desc:
border type.

Possible values are:

  • 'solid'
  • 'dashed'
  • 'dotted'

Since v5.0.0, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the dash array of the line. With borderDashOffset , we can make the line style more flexible.

{

}

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderDas.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the line dash offset. With borderType , we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN lineDashOffset for more details.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To specify how to draw the end points of the line. Possible values are:

  • 'butt': The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
  • 'round': The ends of lines are rounded.
  • 'square': The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is 'butt'. Refer to MDN lineCap for more details.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderJoi.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:

  • 'bevel': Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
  • 'round': Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
  • 'miter': Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the borderMiterLimit property.

Default value is 'bevel'. Refer to MDN lineJoin for more details.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.borderMit.desc:
Since v5.0.0

To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when borderJoin is set as miter.

Default value is 10. Negative、0、Infinity and NaN values are ignored.

Refer to MDN miterLimit for more details.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.shadowBlu.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with shadowColor,shadowOffsetX, shadowOffsetY to set shadow to component.

For example:

{
    shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
    shadowBlur: 10
}

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.shadowCol.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as color.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.shadowOff.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.data.1.blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.position.desc:

Followings are the options:

    Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box. For example:

  position: [10, 10],
  // Relative percentage
  position: ['50%', '50%']

  • 'top'

  • 'right'
  • 'bottom'

  • 'insideRight'
  • 'insideTop'
  • 'insideBottom'

  • 'insideBottomRight'

See: label position.

It is valid only when position is string value (like 'top'、'insideRight').
